PCI.BIO:
Sandra C. Vera-Muñoz is an Associate Professor of Accountancy and KPMG Faculty Fellow. She currently teaches strategic cost management. Her research focuses on corporate environmental disclosures and assurance, sustainability, and judgment and decision making. She received a B.B.A. from the University of Puerto Rico, an MBA from Penn State University, and a Ph.D. from the University of Texas at Austin.

She has published in The Accounting Review, Contemporary Accounting Research, Accounting Horizons, Accounting, Organizations and Society, and the Journal of Business Ethics, among others. She serves in the editorial boards of Auditing: A Journal of Practice & Theory and Behavioral Research in Accounting , and has served in the editorial boards of The Accounting Review, Contemporary Accounting Research, and the Journal of International Accounting Research. She has also served on the Publications Committee of the American Accounting Association, the New Faculty Consortium Planning Committee, and as a faculty adviser for the KPMG Future Diversity Leadership Program. At Notre Dame, Sandra currently serves in the Sustainability Strategy Committee, the Faculty Senate, the Lizzadro Chair Search Committee, and the Building Bridges Mentoring Program.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Strategic Cost Management

Students learn to use publicly available databases, including the Carbon Disclosure Project, to obtain carbon emissions data, CorporateRegister.com (to obtain corporate social responsibility reports), and other relevant websites.

CONGRANT.TITLE: Cost-of-debt effects of carbon emissions and carbon disclosures
CONGRANT.SPONORG: Notre Dame Deloitte Center for Ethical Leadership
CONGRANT.ABSTRACT: Carbon emissions have become an essential element in analyzing a company’s risk profile, potential (“unbooked”) liabilities, and financial performance (Barley 2009). Recent research provides evidence of a negative association between carbon emission levels and firm value, and firms that do not disclose their emissions face a further firm-value penalty for nondisclosure (Matsumura, Prakash, and Vera-Muñoz 2012). Yet, empirical evidence regarding the association between carbon emissions and cost of debt is scarce. We examine empirically two questions: (1) Does the debt market value firms’ voluntary disclosures of their carbon emission levels?; and (2) Does the debt market impound carbon emission levels-related risk and potential claims on the firms’ cash flows in its assessments of firms’ cost of debt? Using a sample of hand-collected carbon emissions and carbon disclosures data for S&P500 firms for 2006 to 2008, we examine the differences in the cost of debt and credit ratings for firms that disclose versus those that do not disclose their carbon emissions, as well as the cost-of- debt effects of carbon emission levels. Since managers choose to disclose their carbon emissions, we correct for self-selection bias in estimating the association between carbon emissions and cost of debt.

CONGRANT.TITLE: KPMG Global Valuation Institute Research Grant
CONGRANT.ABSTRACT: Using hand-collected carbon emissions data for 2006-2008 that S&P 500 firms disclosed voluntarily to the Carbon Disclosure Project, we investigate the relationship between carbon emission levels and firm value. The study is motivated by a relationship between carbon emissions and global climate change that some informed observers expect will drive a redistribution of value from firms that do not control carbon emissions successfully to firms that do (GS Sustain [2009]). Concern about carbon emissions is shared by corporate executives, boards of directors, investors, creditors, standard setters, government regulators, and NGOs. We control for systematic firm-level characteristics that may be associated with managers’ decisions whether or not to voluntarily disclose carbon emissions. We find a negative association between carbon emission levels and firm value, contingent upon firms voluntarily disclosing their carbon emissions in the first place. Our sensitivity analyses and robustness test results are qualitatively similar to our main results.

CONGRANT.TITLE: The Adoption of Western Management Control Systems by Chinese State-Owned Enterprises: Investigating the Determinants of 'Fit'

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Discussion of "The Effect of Audit Judgment Rule on Audit Committees' Questioning on Accounting Estimates" (Kang, Trotman, and Trotman)
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: These discussant comments address the Kang, Trotman, and Trotman study on whether introducing an audit judgment rule -- which is analogous to the business judgment rule applied to corporate officers and directors -- and deploying innovative audit procedures affect audit committee members' questioning on accounting estimates. I believe that the authors have identified a very relevant and timely topic for analysis. In addition, the authors have done a good job motivating the importance of the topic given the increasingly regulated post-Sarbanes-Oxley environment. In these comments, I attempt to place the Kang, Trotman, and Trotman study into context and facilitate generation of research ideas by others. My comments are divided intro three sections: introduction, the evolving roles and responsibilities of audit committees and independent auditors, and comments on research design and some directions for future research.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Firm-value effects of carbon emissions and carbon disclosures
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: Using hand-collected carbon emissions data for 2006 to 2008 that were voluntarily disclosed to the Carbon Disclosure Project by S&P 500 firms, we examine the effects on firm value of carbon emissions and of the act of voluntarily disclosing carbon emissions. Correcting for self-selection bias from managers' decisions to disclose carbon emissions, we find that, on average, for every additional thousand metric tons of carbon emissions, firm value decreases by $212,000, where the median emissions for the disclosing firms in our sample are 1.07 million metric tons. We also examine the firm-value effects of managers' decisions to disclose carbon emissions. We find that the median value of firms that disclose their carbon emissions is about $2.3 billion higher than that of comparable nondisclosing firms. Our results indicate that the markets penalize all firms for their carbon emissions, but a further penalty is imposed on firms that do not disclose emissions information. The results are consistent with the argument that capital markets impound both carbon emissions and the act of voluntary disclosure of this information in firm valuations

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Carbon Footprint Stomps on Firm Value
INTELLCONT.CONTYPEOTHER: Practitioner-oriented monograph published by KPMG's Global Valuation Institute
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: A large carbon footprint has a negative impact on firm value according to Matsumura, Prakash, and Vera-Muñoz (2013). The study, which uses carbon emissions data reported over a 3 year period to the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP) by companies on the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index, finds that firm value decreases, on average, by US$212,000 for every additional thousand metric tons of carbon emissions produced by the firms. This result translates to a firm-value penalty of US$1.4 billion for firms in the third quartile (in terms of carbon emissions) relative to firms in the first quartile. The study also examines the firm-value effects of voluntarily disclosing carbon emissions to the CDP. The study finds that the median firm value of firms that disclose their carbon emissions is about US$2.3 billion higher than the median value of matched non disclosing firms. These results are consistent with the argument that the capital markets impound both carbon emissions and the act of voluntary disclosure of this information in their firm valuations. While both disclosing and non disclosing firms are penalized for their carbon emissions, non disclosers face a further penalty for non disclosure.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Competitive forces and the importance of management control systems in emerging-economy firms: The moderating effect of international market orientation
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: Using survey and archival data from exchange-listed Chinese firms, we investigate the relationship between competitive forces (i.e., the threat of foreign entrants and buyers’ bargaining power) and the importance that the firms place on their management control systems (MCS), and whether the firms’ international market orientation moderates this relationship. We examine five MCS practices—formal procedures, strategic planning, budget targets, approval procedures, and participative budgeting—both as a package and separately. We predict and find a positive association between the threat of foreign entrants and the importance that the firms place on their MCS, but this association is larger for firms competing predominantly in the domestic market than for those competing predominantly in international markets. Further, we predict and find that the association between buyers’ bargaining power and the importance that the firms place on their MCS is larger for firms competing predominantly in international markets than for those competing in domestic markets. We probe deeper into our empirical findings using qualitative data collected from post hoc interviews with managers of Chinese firms and those of international firms operating in China. We discuss the implications of our findings and provide some directions for future research.

INTELLCONT.PUBLISHER: Asia-Pacific Journal of Accounting and Economics
INTELLCONT.TITLE: Exploring the extent and determinants of knowledge sharing in audit engagements
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: Audit firms are faced with increasing demands for audit efficiency and effectiveness. Increasing knowledge sharing in audit engagements can help them respond to this challenge, and this study seeks to advance understanding of the extent and determinants of such sharing. Data collected from auditors of two Big Four audit firms suggest that both firms have high, but far from complete, levels of knowledge sharing. The factors identified as affecting such sharing range from characteristics of the client to attributes of the audit firm, audit team and individual auditors. A framework is proposed for organizing these factors and relationships.

INTELLCONT.PUBLISHER: (Reprint) Fundamentals of Corporate Governance, SAGE Publications, London
INTELLCONT.TITLE: Corporate governance reforms: Redefined expectations of audit committee responsibilities and effectiveness
Accountants' usage of causal business models in the presence of benchmark data: A note
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT:
Performance measurement systems often incorporate cause-and-effect theories in business models, while the literature questions accountants' and managers' ability to use and understand the very business models that they value. We address this question: Does articulation of a business model as a cause-and-effect theory enhance an accountant's evaluation of benchmark data that requires implicit cause-and-effect covariation assessments? We prompt (or do not prompt) accountants with a causal business model and with benchmark data that either support or do not support the model, and ask the accountants to make budget allocation recommendations. We find that accountants prompted with causal-model information are more able to interpret and exploit cause-and-effect covariation information that is implied in the benchmark data. Further, we find that providing causal-model information offers the potential for a beneficial effectbut no detrimental effectin guiding covariation judgments, even when the benchmark data do not support the model. Taken together, our results suggest that in the presence of benchmark data, causal-model information compensates for the lack of causal knowledge by guiding accountants' covariation assessments. We discuss implications for research and practice, and provide directions for future research. Keywords Accountants, Benchmark data; Cause-and-effect business model; Implicit covariation assessments
JEL Descriptors C91, D83, M41

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Enhancing knowledge sharing in public accounting firms
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: The goal of this study is to advance understanding of factors that may enhance or hinder knowledge sharing in public accounting firms, and, in the end, provide practical recommendations for the firms. Attention to this topic is warranted for two reasons. First, today's regulatory environment and new auditing standards have broadened and intensified pressures on CPA firms to enhance the quality, effectiveness, and efficiency of the audit process. Second, knowledge and expertise are unevenly distributed among the members of the audit team. Thus, knowledge sharing can help CPA firms in leveraging the skills, knowledge, and best practices of their professional staff. Against this background, CPA firms' ability to effectively deploy knowledge-sharing activities is increasingly vital to their competitive advantage, including gaining tangible benefits in terms of time and cost reductions. We draw upon prior research in accounting, organizational learning, psychology, and knowledge management to examine the role of three factorsinformation technology, formal and informal interactions among auditors, and reward systemsin encouraging knowledge sharing. We develop recommendations for public accounting firms and suggest several directions for future research.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Corporate governance reforms: Redefined expectations of audit committee responsibilities and effectiveness
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: Comprehensive regulatory changes brought on by recent corporate governance reforms have broadly redefined and re-emphasized the roles and responsibilities of all the participants in a company's financial reporting process. Most notably, these reforms have intensified scrutiny of corporate audit committees, whose role as protectors of investors' interests now attracts substantially higher visibility and expectations. As a result, audit committees face the formidable challenge of effectively overseeing the company's financial reporting process in a dramatically changedand highly chargedcorporate governance environment. This study discusses the new role, responsibilities, and expectations of audit committees in the wake of corporate governance reforms, determinants of audit committee effectiveness, "whistleblower" provisions, key challenges and their ethical implications, and provides some directions for future research. Keywords: Blue Ribbon Committee; Sarbanes-Oxley Act; corporate governance; audit committee effectiveness; whistleblower communication provisions

INTELLCONT.PUBLISHER: Accounting Research Monthly/Accounting Research & Development Foundation
INTELLCONT.TITLE: Exploring the Openness of Information Sharing in Audits and its Main Impediments
Opportunism in Capital Budget Recommendations: The Effects of Past Performance and Its Attributions

PRESENT.NAME: 25th Audit & Assurance Conference
PRESENT.TITLE: Do Audit Firms’ Procedure Descriptions Communicate Service Quality Level? An Experiment Applying New IAASB Assurance Standards
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: Can assurance report users reliably assess service quality via an audit firm’s customized description of its work effort? The answer is important because international assurance standards now mandate such descriptions as the basis for variable assurance limited to less than “audit-level” quality. If users cannot differentiate service quality levels, then (a) the minimum quality level within the “limited assurance” range will likely drive out higher quality/higher cost services, (b) audit firms may compete on report wording rather than on service quality, and (c) limited assurance standards will lack effective enforcement criteria. We conduct an experiment eliciting participants’ confidence judgments after reading actual procedure descriptions for assured greenhouse gas emissions reports. We find that, other things equal, including or explicitly excluding a procedure deemed essential for audit-level assurance did not significantly affect users’ quality perceptions, but varying report format while holding constant procedure descriptions produced confidence judgments ranging from about 60% to about 80%. These results suggest that customized procedure descriptions do not communicate relative assurance quality.

PRESENT.NAME: 2011 Financial Accounting and Reporting Section Conference
PRESENT.TITLE: Carbon Emissions and Firm Value
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: Using hand-collected carbon emissions data for 2006-2008 that S&P 500 firms disclosed voluntarily to the Carbon Disclosure Project, we investigate the relationship between carbon emission levels and firm value. The study is motivated by a relationship between carbon emissions and global climate change that some informed observers expect will drive a redistribution of value from firms that do not control carbon emissions successfully to firms that do (GS Sustain [2009]). Concern about carbon emissions is shared by corporate executives, boards of directors, investors, creditors, standard setters, government regulators, and NGOs. We control for systematic firm-level characteristics that may be associated with managers’ decisions whether or not to voluntarily disclose carbon emissions. We find a negative association between carbon emission levels and firm value, contingent upon firms voluntarily disclosing their carbon emissions in the first place. Our sensitivity analyses and robustness test results are qualitatively similar to our main results.

PRESENT.NAME: 2011 Management Accounting Section Research and Case Conference
PRESENT.TITLE: Carbon Emissions and Firm Value
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: Using hand-collected carbon emissions data for 2006-2008 that S&P 500 firms disclosed voluntarily to the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP), we investigate the relationship between carbon emission levels and both firm value and the cost of capital components of firm value: cost of equity capital and cost of debt. The study is motivated by a relationship between carbon emissions and global climate change that some informed observers expect will drive a redistribution of value from firms that do not control carbon emissions successfully to firms that do (GS Sustain 2009). Indeed, Goldman Sachs’ GS Sustain report asserts that “the equity market is only beginning to recognize the magnitude of impact the transition to a low carbon global economy will have on companies’ competitive positions and long-term valuations” (GS Sustain 2009, 2). Concern about carbon emissions is shared by corporate executives, boards of directors, domestic and global investors, creditors, and standard setters, as well as by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and other government regulators, and NGOs (e.g., CDP and Ceres). We use Heckman’s (1979) two-stage approach to control for systematic firm-level characteristics that may be associated with managers’ decisions whether or not to voluntarily disclose carbon emissions. We predict and find a negative association between carbon emission levels and firm value, and a positive association between carbon emission levels and cost of debt, contingent upon firms voluntarily disclosing their carbon emissions in the first place. Surprisingly, we find a negative association between carbon emission levels and cost of equity capital. Our sensitivity analyses and robustness test results are qualitatively similar to our main results. We discuss the implications of our findings for managers, investors, regulators, standard setters, and the U.S. Congress, and provide some directions for future research.

PRESENT.NAME: 2010 JAAF/KPMG Foundation Conference
PRESENT.TITLE: Carbon Emissions and Firm Value
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: Using hand-collected carbon emissions data for 2006-2008 that S&P 500 firms disclosed voluntarily to the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP), we investigate the relationship between carbon emission levels and both firm value and the cost of capital components of firm value: cost of equity capital and cost of debt. The study is motivated by a relationship between carbon emissions and global climate change that some informed observers expect will drive a redistribution of value from firms that do not control carbon emissions successfully to firms that do (GS Sustain 2009). Indeed, Goldman Sachs’ GS Sustain report asserts that “the equity market is only beginning to recognize the magnitude of impact the transition to a low carbon global economy will have on companies’ competitive positions and long-term valuations” (GS Sustain 2009, 2). Concern about carbon emissions is shared by corporate executives, boards of directors, domestic and global investors, creditors, and standard setters, as well as by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and other government regulators, and NGOs (e.g., CDP and Ceres). We use Heckman’s (1979) two-stage approach to control for systematic firm-level characteristics that may be associated with managers’ decisions whether or not to voluntarily disclose carbon emissions. We predict and find a negative association between carbon emission levels and firm value, and a positive association between carbon emission levels and cost of debt, contingent upon firms voluntarily disclosing their carbon emissions in the first place. Surprisingly, we find a negative association between carbon emission levels and cost of equity capital. Our sensitivity analyses and robustness test results are qualitatively similar to our main results. We discuss the implications of our findings for managers, investors, regulators, standard setters, and the U.S. Congress, and provide some directions for future research.

PRESENT.TITLE: Carbon Emissions and Firm Value
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: Using hand-collected carbon emissions data for 2006-2008 that S&P 500 firms disclosed voluntarily to the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP), we investigate the relationship between carbon emission levels and both firm value and the cost of capital components of firm value: cost of equity capital and cost of debt. The study is motivated by a relationship between carbon emissions and global climate change that some informed observers expect will drive a redistribution of value from firms that do not control carbon emissions successfully to firms that do (GS Sustain 2009). Indeed, Goldman Sachs’ GS Sustain report asserts that “the equity market is only beginning to recognize the magnitude of impact the transition to a low carbon global economy will have on companies’ competitive positions and long-term valuations” (GS Sustain 2009, 2). Concern about carbon emissions is shared by corporate executives, boards of directors, domestic and global investors, creditors, and standard setters, as well as by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and other government regulators, and NGOs (e.g., CDP and Ceres). We use Heckman’s (1979) two-stage approach to control for systematic firm-level characteristics that may be associated with managers’ decisions whether or not to voluntarily disclose carbon emissions. Our sensitivity analyses and robustness test results are qualitatively similar to our main results. We discuss the implications of our findings for managers, investors, regulators, standard setters, and the U.S. Congress, and provide some directions for future research.

PRESENT.NAME: 2010 Management Accounting Section Research and Case Conference
PRESENT.TITLE: The Effects of Market Competition and International Market Orientation on Management Control System Use by Emerging-Market Publicly Listed Companies
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: Using survey and archival data from exchange-listed Chinese firms, we investigate the relationship between competitive forces (i.e., threat of foreign entrants and buyers’ bargaining power) and the importance the firms place on management control systems (MCS), and whether the firms’ international market orientation moderates this relationship. We examine five MCS (i.e., formal procedures, strategic planning, budget targets, approval procedures, and participative budgeting), both as a package and disaggregated. We predict and find a positive association between the threat of foreign entrants and the importance the firms place on MCS, but this association is greater for firms that compete predominantly in the domestic market than for firms that compete predominantly in international markets. Further, we predict and find that the association between the buyers’ bargaining power and the importance the firms place on MCS is greater for firms that compete predominantly in international markets than for those that compete in domestic markets. We probe deeper on our empirical findings using qualitative data collected from post-hoc interviews with managers of Chinese firms and of international firms operating in China. We discuss the implications of our findings and provide some directions for future research.

RESPROG.TITLE: A Sea Change in International Standards on Assurance on Sustainability Information: Can Report Users Infer the Assurance Level Provided?
RESPROG.DESC: ABSTRACT: Recent international auditing and assurance standards on sustainability information eliminate the practitioner’s established responsibility to obtain “moderate assurance” for review-level engagements. Instead, the standards presume that each report user can discern the level of assurance provided, which can and does vary across individual engagements. Specifically, the new standards assume that report users can infer from the procedures described in the report where assurance falls along a continuum from “just above clearly inconsequential” to just below “high” or audit-level assurance, raising the question: can assurance report users reliably infer the assurance level provided? The answer is important because if users cannot infer the assurance level provided, then many assurance report users will be misled, thus providing evidence of the new assurance standards’ inability to close a communication gap between the assurance provider’s report and report users. We conduct an experiment eliciting confidence judgments about assured greenhouse gas emissions reports after participants read actual procedure descriptions applying the new standards. We find that, other things being equal, including or explicitly excluding a procedure deemed essential for audit-level assurance did not significantly affect users’ confidence perceptions. Further, the confidence assessments of participants who received a report with procedures indicative of audit-level assurance were not different from those who received an otherwise identical report listing procedures which would not achieve audit-level assurance. These results suggest that customized procedure descriptions alone cannot effectively communicate the assurance level obtained.
RESPROG.JOURNAL_NAME: Journal of Accounting and Public Policy

RESPROG.TITLE: Doing more good or doing less bad? The effects of framing and status quo bias on managers' corporate social responsibility investment decisions
Risk-relevance of voluntary carbon emission disclosures
RESPROG.DESC:
We study the association between voluntary disclosures of carbon emissions and two components of firm value: cost of equity capital and cost of debt. Our inquiry is important because stakeholders are increasingly concerned about the impact of climate-change risks on firm valuation. Yet, with little regulatory pressure for public companies to disclose these risks, such disclosure is largely voluntary. We predict that, other things equal, disclosing (vs. non-disclosing) carbon emissions is associated with both a lower cost of equity capital and a lower cost of debt. We use carbon disclosure choices of S&P 500 firms for years 2006-2008 from CDP. Because firms choose whether to disclose their emissions, we control for self-selection bias using propensity score matching to match disclosing and non-disclosing firms. We construct a composite implied cost of equity capital using the median of four measures used in the accounting and finance literatures. Our doubly robust regression results show that the cost of equity of disclosing firms is 21.6 basis points lower than the cost of equity of non-disclosing firms. Further, using secondary bond market trading data we find that the cost of debt of disclosing firms is 89 basis points lower than the cost of debt of non-disclosing firms. Our results are consistent with the argument that the capital markets price climate change-related risks by imputing a higher penalty for firms that do not disclose their carbon emissions.
Status: Working paper

FACDEV.TITLE: PwC Accounting Symposium and Tax Colloquium
FACDEV.DESC: The Symposium and Colloquium are designed to give faculty the opportunity to connect with subject matter experts from PwC. The programs update faculty in a live group delivery format and features a variety of tax and accounting issues. The Accounting Symposium is specifically designed for financial accounting and auditing faculty focusing on current technical updates and important issues facing the profession. The Tax Colloquium focuses on current tax related developments and issues. Both programs are complimentary and are hosted by keynote experts and practitioners in their respective fields.

FACDEV.TITLE: KPMG's 2010 National Faculty Symposium
FACDEV.DESC: This is a one-and-a-half-day event that highlights current issues and developments in the accounting profession. The symposium topics included the following: Department of Professional Practice Update (Accounting, SEC, IFRS, and Auditing); a technical update focusing on the latest issues in Mergers & Acquisitions along with the effect of IFRS on Information Systems; Global Sustainability: the newest practice about the growing client needs around sustainability and the future opportunities for students in this area; Faculty Initiatives and Classroom Tools: National leaders demonstrated the latest tools, developed by KPMG, that can be used to bring the profession into the classroom and for use in research; and State of the Profession Update.
